items.name: Niagara Falls
items.description: The most powerful waterfall in North America, comprising three sections: Horseshoe, Bridal Veil, and American Falls
historical_facts: First documented in 1697 by explorer Louis Hennepin
Became a tourist icon in the 19th century, hosting daredevil stunts in barrels and boats
items.features: Nightly illumination, boat tours on the Maid of the Mist

items.name: American Falls
items.description: Less powerful but visually striking due to rugged rock formations
historical_facts: Diverted completely for six months in 1969 to study erosion

items.name: Whistler Falls
items.seasonality: Best visited in spring (snowmelt) or autumn
items.description: Hidden in a forest of maple and pine, offering serene isolation broken only by the sound of rushing water
historical_facts: Named after a 19th-century naturalist painter who captured its beauty
items.features: Access via a scenic trail with a suspension bridge

items.name: Hidden Spring Falls
items.seasonality: Active only after heavy rains or in spring
items.description: A petite waterfall fed by underground springs
historical_facts: Sacred site for the Iroquois, believed to have healing properties
items.features: Surrounded by wild orchid fields (blooming in June)

items.name: Eagle’s Nest Falls
items.description: Plunges from a cliff crevice, creating a 'rainbow mist' inside the cave
items.features: Requires climbing skills and a flashlight to explore

items.name: Cascade Glen Creek
items.seasonality: Year-round, but icy and hazardous in winter
items.description: A chain of seven small waterfalls in a narrow gorge
historical_facts: Site of 19th-century slate mining for construction
items.features: Fossils dating back 400 million years along the trail
